<@U0DMFJC0H|we-build-peter> shared a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/we-build-peter/F0J9U02NL/What_the_hell_is_DSM___Background_for_our_Wed__chat_|What the hell is DSM? (Background for our Wed. chat)>

file.name: What_the_hell_is_DSM___Background_for_our_Wed__chat_
file.title: What the hell is DSM? (Background for our Wed. chat)
file.preview:
Digital Single Market (DSM) is a move to eliminate barriers within the EU for digital goods and services. If implemented smartly, a DSM would make cross-country purchases easier and be a boon for growth and innovation.

The details matter though. If implemented the wrong way, this DSM could hinder the growth and innovation we’ve been seeing in the Android app development space. There are some new rules being discussed that could slow down the evolution of the Internet ecosystem, block newcomers, and slow Internet services.

One concern we have is whether small companies and devs will be responsible for making user data portable (even if it's anonymized). Another proposal would make you liable for copyright violations committed by users. The DSM might require companies to have data privacy officers -- but that could be limited only to big companies.

This huge package of proposals will undoubtedly impact what you do, and there are a million questions. Go ahead and ask them. Now or Wednesday at 17:00 GMT.

Claudia is in the trenches on this issue, and will be here to fill us in.

text: Question for the DSM chat (credit to <@U0548MM6B>): Will new regulations make devs responsible for storing and making portable user analytics?
<@U0DQYPAGZ|claudia_appsalliance> has joined the channel

Let's get some questions, comments and concerns going over in <#C0GMUND6Z>.

Digital Single Market (DSM) is a move to eliminate barriers within the EU for digital goods and services. If implemented smartly, a DSM would make cross-country purchases easier and be a boon for growth and innovation.

One concern we have is whether small companies and devs will be responsible for making user data portable (even if it's anonymized). text: Comcast strikes again! Read it in the intranet paper! <http://consumerist.com/2016/01/12/why-is-comcast-interrupting-my-web-browsing-to-upsell-me-on-a-new-modem/>

attachments.title: Why Is Comcast Interrupting My Web-Browsing To Upsell Me On A New Modem?
attachments.text:
Comcast says that the only way for Consumerist reader BB to stop seeing these pop-up alerts is to upgrade his modem.We already know that Comcast can — and does — inject alerts into users’ web browsers to alert them to potential copyright infringement, but the nation’s largest Internet provider can also use this ability to interrupt your enjoyment of the web in order to remind you to upgrade your modem.
Consumerist reader and Comcast customer “BB” says that the cable company upgraded the network in his area in recent months, and has been writing and calling him regularly about upgrading his modem ever since. 
“For months we received multiple letters in the mail, explaining how we were missing out on the great new capabilities of their network,” writes BB. “This eventually escalated to repeated phone calls from Comcast, stating that we should really upgrade our modem.”
Thing is, BB owns the modem he uses and he’s experienced no problems with service or speeds since the network upgrade. He’d rather not spend money on a new modem — or pay Comcast too much to rent one from the company — when what he has is working just fine.
And BB is not some minor Internet user with an ancient desktop computer that he only uses to check email once a week. In fact, he’s a software developer living — like many of us — in a home with multiple web-connected devices. 
“We stream Netflix and YouTube and our Internet speed is great for everything we need,” he writes. “Why should I spend the money?” 
BB knows that sometimes customers can indeed be left out in the cold by using old tech — just ask all those people who had to scramble for digital antennas and cable boxes when that changeover happened — so he called Comcast to ask exactly what he was missing out on with his old modem. He says the support rep would only tell him that he wasn’t enjoying the full benefits of the upgraded modem, but failed to provide any real technical info about what this meant. 
“Now they’ve moved to more aggressive measures to try to get me to upgrade,” writes BB. “The other day as I was browsing the web on my phone, on my home WiFi, I got a pop-up notice while browsing on wired.com.” (see screenshot above)
In big red letters, the notice alerts BB that there is some “Action Needed” on his service.
It reads:
“Our records indicate that the cable modem, which you currently use for your XFINITY Internet service, may not be able to receive the full range of our speeds. To ensure you’re receiving the full benefits of your XFINITY Internet service, please replace your cable modem.”
“This feels like a step too far,” writes BB. “It just feels invasive in a way I’m not comfortable with.”
A Comcast exec we talked to argued that this is not an attempt to upsell the customer on a new modem, and instead characterized the alert as an educational tool to let the customer know that their device may be nearing the end of its life cycle. They explained that while an older modem may work, it may also no longer be receiving necessary, regular software updates and bug fixes.
The exec points to Comcast’s impending rollout of DOCSIS 3.1 technology — which allows for gigabit Internet speeds over existing cable lines. Taking advantage of that leap in speeds will also require users to switch out to newer modems.  
Unfortunately for BB, the only way to stop the upgrade alerts from showing up in his web browser is to eventually upgrade his modem. There is currently no way to opt out of these injected notices.
For now, BB seems content with his setup.
“If they want me to upgrade my modem so badly they can send me a new one, or put a credit on my bill to pay for one that I buy myself,” he writes. “Until then, I’m perfectly happy with my Internet speed and will use my modem until it stops working.”
Was this helpful? We’re a non-profit! You can get more stories like this in our twice weekly ad-free newsletter! Click here to sign up.
attachments.fallback: Consumerist Link: Why Is Comcast Interrupting My Web-Browsing To Upsell Me On A New Modem?

text: I don't get why they haven't been dragged to court yet.
Isn't this illegal?
I agree with someone in the reddit comments.
It's like reading someones letters, it's illegal.
while that would annoy me, i think a popup telling me my modem is outdated would be pretty low on the "why comcast sucks" scale
they've done... way worse haha
and i don't think a notification about your modem is really a privacy issue, though the notifications about copyright infringement definitely are like reading your mail
(the notifications they allude to in the first paragraph)
i mean they're an ISP, of course they'll know what kind of modem you have, it's not a state secret
that said, i don't need a popup in my browser telling me to upgrade, an email would suffice just fine
<@U0546QERR>: injecting data means that they read it which is an invasion of privacy.
where are they injecting data?
sounds to me like they don't care what you're doing online, they're just flagging users that have a < docsis 3.1 modem and showing a popup once in a while

well, they don't care in the modem case. as I said there's still that issue that came up months ago about the copyright detection, in which case they're definitely reading your traffic and i agree that's bad
How can you suddenly see an ad of theirs constantly?
I doubt they pay Google for every one of them
they inject their own data but they're not messing with what you're doing
by data i mean the popup
they're an ISP so they have direct access to the traffic from any of their customers
don't need to pay google
Wowowow
That doesn't give them any right
It's not because your Facebook notification is passing through your company's network while you're at work that they can access it
That makes no sense
they're not reading data though in this instance, they're just adding _extra_ data
that's still kind of shady
it's like if the post office inserted extra stuff in the envelope
i get mail from the PO sometimes :stuck_out_tongue:
every time i change my address, a nice packet of coupons
lol
that's what email is for then :wink:
or sms
yeah i'm definitely not arguing against the fact that the pop-ups are super annoying lol
i don't really think comcast is using the modem pop-up as an upsell or anything like that though
the modem rental fee doesn't make a whole lot of profit iirc
besides, if you already have your own modem and you get that pop-up, you'll probably just look to buy a newer modem not-from-comcast
if you're renting, then they're already getting your money
<@U0546QERR>: you can't just insert it without reading it
And you have no idea whether they're saving that data
whether or not they're saving it doesn't matter
It's private

sure they can.. they're already delivering your traffic. they see they're delivering traffic to a customer (they don't care what it is), see that customer has a docsis 2.0, so they decide to inject the pop-up
It's not because I'm the postman that I can read every letter I deliver
they don't need to know what's in the letter, just that you're getting letters :stuck_out_tongue:
Well same goes for Comcast
They shouldn't know what's in the packet
Just send it and that's it
You just contradicted yourself
they don't need to read your traffic to know what kind of modem you have, if that's what you mean
that's in the billing system from when you sign up
I know
But I'm talking about injecting the ad
why they didnt just sms/call/send a letter is the question
It shouldn't even be a question
Injecting data is wrong
Reading your data is wrong

yeah this line is pretty surprising honestly
> “This eventually escalated to repeated phone calls from Comcast, stating that we should really upgrade our modem.”
phone calls are expensive
and as i said logically they're not making much money from the modem rentals, so i wonder how that's worth it
im pretty sure they make a lot of money from modem rentals

modem costs me or you lets say $100.. we all know everything has markup glancing around im seeing people claim markup on modems is on a huge range of 15% to some claiming 300%. Lets just assume that since cable companies buy in the thousands they are surely getting at least 20%. So 80 dollars is their cost divide by 5 and you have 16 months
I don't see how getting a modem would be beneficial
that’s great except that in areas with no competition they charge you to bring you the modem
You're only getting 1.5mb/s from comcast :troll:
that is usually at least $40 if not more
so in 8 months most of the time they can make their money back
If Google Fiber were in town
I'd call Comcast and be like
"Yo let's make a deal"
yeah they might be making a decent bit, depends on how long their modems last and the maintenance overhead
Just to fuck with them
And then go to Google Fiber
the gateways also include a router though so they're worth a bit more than just a straight modem
Just get your own equipment
Cheaper and better
yeah, for sure
on that note.. onhub is dope as fuck
its got some problems but otherwise dope as fuck
just fyi
The next time I'm buying a router and switch I'll just get some stuff that I can configure myself
If I can afford those

attachments.title: The five big lies of the encryption debate
attachments.text: It’s become impossible to talk about encryption policy without lying. Over the last year, we’ve been talking about encryption a lot, driven by a string of speeches from FBI director James Comey....
